\5900 TX Tenant\5902 1 of 10Complex  Name: Estates on Frankford Apt #: 3123
Apartment Lease Contract - Texas
Date of Lease Contract: 07/01/2024
(when the lease contract is filled out) (Mo./Day/Yr.)
1.PARTIES.  This Lease  Contract is between  you, each of the resident(s) 
executing this Lease Contract (see page 10) and us the owner:
Estates on Frankford
(Complex Name)
You’ve agreed to rent Apartment Unit No. 3123 at
7575 Frankford Road #3123 
(Street Address)
in, Dallas Texas, 75252
(City) (Zip Code)
for use as a private residence only.  The term "you" refers to all residents 
executing this Lease Contract.  The terms "we," "us," and "our" refer to the 
owner listed above and not to property managers or anyone else.  The 
complex, of which your apartment unit is a part, is referred to as the 
"Property."  Your apartment unit does not include any of the common areas 
of the Property including, without limitation, the exterior of your front 
door.
Co-Signers.  If anyone else has co-signed on this Lease Contract, a 
separate Agreement To Be Co-Signer For Resident is required.
2.LEASE TERM.The initial term of the Lease Contract begins
on 08/06/2024 and ends
(Mo./Day/Yr.)
at midnight 08/05/2025 .
(Mo./Day/Yr.)
This Lease Contract will automatically renew month-to-month and 
continues month-to-month thereafter unless either party gives sixty (60) 
days prior written notice of termination pursuant to Section 46 below.
3.RENTAL PAYMENTS.  You will pay $2,117.00 per month for total 
monthly rent, payable in advance and without demand (reduced during the 
period of the concessions described in Section 72 below, if any).  You must 
pay your rent on or before the 1st day of each month (due date) with no 
grace period.  Your rent payment, by one check or money order (multiple 
checks will not be accepted) payable to the Estates on Frankford,  must be 
hand-delivered or mailed to the on-site leasing office.  Electronic payment 
of rent may also be used.  Include your resident I.D. number in the lower 
left-hand corner of your payment.  Rent is not paid until received by us at 
the on-site leasing office or electronically.  The following are not 
acceptable rent payments and you will receive no credit for them against 
rent due: 1) a payment of cash; 2) a rent credit or concession not 
specifically agreed to by us in writing; or 3) a rent adjustment in exchange 
for goods or services given to our employee(s).  We may, at our option, 
require at any time that you pay all rent and other sums by certified or 
cashier's check or money order.  We may limit or deny you the use of 
electronic rent payment at any time without notice.  Prior to moving in, you 
shall pay us prorated rent (see Section 72) representing rent from the date 
of occupancy through the end of that month.  If you take occupancy of your 
apartment unit after the 24th day of any month, in addition to the prorated 
rent payment described above, your next full month’s rent shall also be due 
at the time you execute this Lease Contract.  Thereafter, each monthly 
rental payment shall be for a full month's rent.  If you are leasing a 
furnished apartment unit, you must complete a "Furniture/Personal 
Property Inventory Agreement."  Otherwise, your apartment unit will be 
unfurnished.  No partial rent payments are allowed.  Late rent can only be 
paid by personal check if a notice to pay has not yet been served on you.  
After that time, late rent must be paid by a cashier's check or money order. 
You must not withhold or offset rent unless authorized by statute.  If you 
default in your obligations under this Lease Contract, you 
acknowledge and agree that any rental concessions and/or discounts 
which have been extended to you in connection with this Lease 
Contract are rescinded, and you agree to reimburse us for the full 
amount and/or value of any rental concessions, leasing incentives 
and/or discounts set forth this Lease Contract.
4.DEPOSIT.

If you are leasing a 
furnished apartment unit, you must complete a "Furniture/Personal 
Property Inventory Agreement."  Otherwise, your apartment unit will be 
unfurnished.  No partial rent payments are allowed.  Late rent can only be 
paid by personal check if a notice to pay has not yet been served on you.  
After that time, late rent must be paid by a cashier's check or money order. 
You must not withhold or offset rent unless authorized by statute.  If you 
default in your obligations under this Lease Contract, you 
acknowledge and agree that any rental concessions and/or discounts 
which have been extended to you in connection with this Lease 
Contract are rescinded, and you agree to reimburse us for the full 
amount and/or value of any rental concessions, leasing incentives 
and/or discounts set forth this Lease Contract.
4.DEPOSIT.  For all purposes and for all residents, your deposit is the "Total 
Deposit" specified in Section 72 and is due on or before the date this Lease 
Contract is signed.  Whether or not the deposit tabulation in Section 72 is 
completed, your deposits are not designated for specific purposes, and your 
entire deposit may be used by us for any purposes specified in this Lease 
Contract or otherwise allowed by law, including without limitation: (1) 
compensation to us for your default in the payment of rent; (2) the repair 
of damages to your apartment unit caused by negligence, carelessness, 
accident or abuse; (3) the cleaning of the Premises, including shampooing 
of the carpets, upon termination of your tenancy; (4) to remedy future 
defaults by you in any obligation under the Lease Contract and to restore, 
replace or return personal property or appurtenances; (5) damages caused 
by animals, including defleaing, deodorizing and/or shampooing; (6) 
compensation to us for your default in the payment of any utilities required to be paid by you pursuant to the terms of this Lease Contract or any 
addenda hereto; and (7) any other costs, damages, charges or items for 
which we are entitled to collect pursuant to the terms of this Lease 
Contract.  If we agree to permit you to pay an applicable pet deposit in 
installments, you agree to make installment payments as follows:
1st$ due date
2nd$ due date
3rd$ due date
5.NON-REFUNDABLE ADMINISTRATIVE FEE.  At the time of 
move-in, in addition to all other rent and other payments due under the 
Lease, you will be charged a Non-Refundable Administrative Fee in the 
amount of $   0.00. This fee is compensation to us for our administrative 
time and effort in leasing the apartment unit to you.
6.OCCUPANTS AND RESTRICTIONS.  The apartment unit will be 
occupied only by you and the other occupants identified in your Rental 
Application.  No other person may occupy the apartment unit for more than 
three (3) consecutive days and no more than six (6) random days during 
any period of six (6) consecutive months without our prior, written consent.  
This lease prohibits subleasing as set forth in Section 42 below.
7.ANIMALS.  No animals (including assistive/support animals) are allowed 
(even temporarily) anywhere in your apartment unit or on the Property 
without the execution of a separate Animal Agreement, except for service 
animals of disabled non-residents.  Animals include animal-mammals, 
reptiles, birds, amphibians, fish, rodents, arachnids and insects.  You are 
responsible for your animals while you are on the Property.  If in our sole 
and absolute judgment your animal becomes a nuisance by, without 
limitation, biting, barking, or otherwise interfering with other residents' 
peaceful enjoyment of the Property, you shall permanently remove the 
animal from the Property upon written notice to you.  If an animal has been 
in the apartment unit for any duration of time during your term of 
occupancy (with or without our consent), we will charge you for defleaing, 
deodorizing and/or shampooing carpeting in addition to damages caused 
by your animal.  Further, you acknowledge that flea control is your 
responsibility while you occupy your apartment unit.  If you bring an 
unauthorized animal into your apartment unit, in addition to our having all 
other remedies provided by law, you agree to pay us three hundred dollar 
($300) as liquidated damages for our time, inconvenience, and overhead in 
enforcing animal restrictions and rules for other than assistive/support 
animals.

If an animal has been 
in the apartment unit for any duration of time during your term of 
occupancy (with or without our consent), we will charge you for defleaing, 
deodorizing and/or shampooing carpeting in addition to damages caused 
by your animal.  Further, you acknowledge that flea control is your 
responsibility while you occupy your apartment unit.  If you bring an 
unauthorized animal into your apartment unit, in addition to our having all 
other remedies provided by law, you agree to pay us three hundred dollar 
($300) as liquidated damages for our time, inconvenience, and overhead in 
enforcing animal restrictions and rules for other than assistive/support 
animals.  You agree that our damages from your bringing an unauthorized 
animal into your apartment unit would be extremely difficult to calculate.  
You agree to not allow any animal on the premises that has a history of 
acting in an aggressive manner or causing an injury to any human or other 
animal or that has caused property damage.  We recommend that you 
advise the on-site manager if you are considering a new pet to be sure that 
it will qualify for approval.
8.ADDITIONAL RENT.  If we have not received your rent by the third 
(3rd) day of each month you will be required to pay a reasonable initial late 
charge on the fourth (4th) day of the month equal to five percent (5%) of 
the rent due, plus a reasonable additional late charge each day thereafter 
equal to one percent (1%) of the rent due until the amount is paid in full, 
up to a maximum late fee equal to ten percent (10%) of the rent due.  You 
agree that these late charges are a reasonable estimate of uncertain damages 
to us that are incapable of precise calculation and result from late payment 
of rent.  You will pay a charge of fifty dollars ($50) for each returned check 
or other form of payment that is dishonored for any reason, plus late 
charges.  If your check is returned to us unpaid, it must be replaced with a 
cashier's check or money order, and rent for the following three (3) months 
must also be paid by cashier's check or money order.  All charges in this 
Section 8, and any other charges authorized by this Lease Contract are 
considered additional rent.
9.APPLICATION OF DEPOSIT.  If you decline occupancy following 
your execution of this Lease Contract, you shall be in default under this 
Lease Contract and you agree that the deposit shall be applied to the period 
of time during which the apartment unit is vacant following the date on 
which your lease term began.  This remedy is in addition to, and not in 
place of, any other remedies we may have under this Lease Contract or 
applicable law.
10.RELETTING CHARGE.  You will be liable to us for a reletting charge 
equal to eighty-five percent (85%) of the highest monthly rent during the 
Lease Contract term or any extensions thereof, if you:
(1)fail to give written move-out notice pursuant to Section 46 below; or
(2)move-out without paying rent in full for the entire Lease Contract 
term or renewal period; or
(3)move-out at our demand because of your default; or
(4)are judicially evicted; or
(5)fail to take occupancy after executing this Lease Contract.

\5900 TX Tenant\5902 2 of 10The reletting charge is not a Lease Contract cancellation fee or a buyout 
fee.  It does not release you from continued liability for future or past-due 
rent, charges for cleaning, repairing, repainting, or lock changes, or other 
sums due.  Rather, the reletting charge is a liquidated amount covering only 
part of our damages, that is, our time, effort, and expense in finding and 
processing a replacement.  Such items are uncertain and difficult to 
ascertain – particularly those relating to make-ready, inconvenience, 
paperwork, advertising, showing apartments, utilities for showing, 
checking prospects, overhead, marketing costs, and locator-service fees.  
You agree that the reletting charge is due whether or not our reletting 
attempts succeed.  If no amount is stipulated, you must pay our actual 
reletting costs so far as they can be determined.
11.UTILITIES.  You must pay for all utilities, related deposits, and charges 
on utility bills connected in your name during the terms of this Lease 
Contract and any renewals or extensions.  You must arrange to have your 
utilities turned on three (3) days in advance of your move-in.  You will not 
be permitted to take occupancy unless you have arranged for your utility 
service by telephone from the apartment manager's office or have 
presented the apartment manager with a dated receipt from the utility 
company evidencing payment.  You must not allow utilities to be 
disconnected – including disconnection for not paying your bills – until the 
Lease Contract term or renewal period ends.  If you permit your utilities to 
be disconnected prior to such time, you will be charged a reasonable fee of 
$15 as additional rent in addition to any other charges we incur on your 
behalf for such utilities to cover our costs in handling your utility account.  
Some exterior lighting immediately adjacent to your apartment unit and 
controlled by a photocell, automatic control time clocks for landscape 
sprinklers and electric garage door openers (for which you have no 
working switch) may be wired to your electric meter.  You accept 
responsibility to determine this fact from the on-premises Manager and to 
pay the electricity for such items as a condition of this Lease Contract.  
Cable channels that we provide, if any, may be changed during the Lease 
Contract term if the change applies to all residents.  We do not represent or 
warrant the quality or availability of cable television whether or not cable 
service is provided by us or by an independent cable company.  You agree 
that in the event of any interruption in your cable, telephone or internet 
service, you shall look solely to the provider of that service for 
reimbursement of any loss.  If you are paying us directly for cable, alarm 
or other utility services, we are making such services available to you based 
upon an agreement which we have entered into with the providers of such 
services.  Therefore, notwithstanding anything to the contrary set forth in 
the Lease Contract, we may increase the rate for such service upon thirty-
five (35) days prior written notice, or we may terminate such services upon 
thirty (30) days prior written notice in the event that our agreement with 
the provider terminates.  Regardless of whether you pay a cable provider, 
us or both for cable television services to your apartment unit, your failure 
to pay any portion of your cable television bill may result in termination of 
all of your cable television service, in addition to any other remedies which 
we or the cable provider may have pursuant to the Lease Contract or at law.  
If we provide wireless internet service for your use, we are doing so 
through a third-party provider.  As such, we do not represent or warrant the 
quality or availability of such service, nor do we make any representation 
or warranty regarding the safety of information received or sent over such 
system.  By using the wireless internet service, you expressly waive any 
Claims (as defined in Section 19 below) you may have against us based 
upon such use.  If any of the utilities for your apartment unit including, 
without limitation, water, gas and trash removal are submetered or the cost 
allocated to you, we will attach the appropriate addenda to this Lease 
Contract in accordance with state and local statutes and rules.  The rent set 
forth in Section 3 above includes a charge for pest control.
12.REIMBURSEMENT.

If we provide wireless internet service for your use, we are doing so 
through a third-party provider.  As such, we do not represent or warrant the 
quality or availability of such service, nor do we make any representation 
or warranty regarding the safety of information received or sent over such 
system.  By using the wireless internet service, you expressly waive any 
Claims (as defined in Section 19 below) you may have against us based 
upon such use.  If any of the utilities for your apartment unit including, 
without limitation, water, gas and trash removal are submetered or the cost 
allocated to you, we will attach the appropriate addenda to this Lease 
Contract in accordance with state and local statutes and rules.  The rent set 
forth in Section 3 above includes a charge for pest control.
12.REIMBURSEMENT.  You must promptly pay or reimburse us for loss, 
damage, consequential damages, government fines or charges (including 
re-inspection fees or fines related to such inspections of your apartment 
unit), or cost of repairs or service to your apartment unit or the Property 
because of a violation of this Lease Contract or the Rules and Regulations, 
improper use, negligence, other conduct by you, your occupants, or your 
guests, or from any other cause directly related to the use of your apartment 
unit or the Property by you, your occupants, or your guests not due to our 
negligence or fault as allowed by law, except for damages by Acts of God 
to the extent they could not be mitigated by your actions or inaction.  These 
damages include, without limitation: (1) damage to doors (shower, 
sliding, entry), windows, mirrors or screens; (2) damage from wind, 
rain or water caused by leaving windows or doors open; (3) damages 
caused by your failure to timely report moisture or water leaks in your 
apartment unit leading to mold or other damage; (4) costs which you 
are required to pay under the Bed Bug Addendum; (5) damages to 
gates; (6) the need for additional pest control in your apartment unit 
caused by your failure to maintain your apartment unit in a clean 
condition; (7) damages resulting from smoking in your apartment 
unit (smoke odors, discolorations, and other smoking-associated 
damages are not considered normal wear and tear); (8) any repairs or 
damage caused by improper use of plumbing or causing obstruction 
in the pipes; (9) damage to electrical outlets or wiring (such as 
broken/missing faceplates); and (10) damage associated with the use 
of natural gas, including but not limited to damage to your oven, cook 
top, stove or other appliances.  We may require payment at any time for such items, including advance payment of repairs for which you are liable.  
A 15% fee to cover our overhead will be added to each request for 
reimbursement.  Any delay in our demanding sums you owe is not a 
waiver.  By executing this Lease Contract, you acknowledge having 
received a copy of the "Resident Handbook" including "Energy 
Conservation and Appliances - Operations and Maintenance" describing 
generally how to use and maintain your apartment unit, and particularly 
noting instructions to stop toilet overflow.  For purposes of this Section, 
you shall be deemed to be negligent if you fail to report a maintenance 
issue in your apartment unit and such failure causes damage to the 
Property.
13.DELAY OF OCCUPANCY.  If occupancy is or will be delayed for 
construction, repairs, cleaning, or a previous resident's holding over, we're 
not liable to you for the delay subject to state law.  The Lease Contract will 
remain in force subject to: (1) abatement of rent on a daily basis during the 
delay; and (2) your right to terminate in writing.  After termination, you are 
entitled only to a refund of deposit(s) and to any rent paid.  If there is a 
delay and we have not given notice of delay as set forth below, you may 
terminate up to the date when the apartment unit is ready for occupancy, 
but not later. If we give written notice to you that the apartment unit is not 
ready but will be ready on a specific date, you may terminate the Lease 
Contract within one (1) day of your receiving the notice, but not later.  The 
date on which the apartment unit is ready is considered the new effective 
Lease Contract date for all purposes.
14.DISCLOSURE RIGHTS; PHOTO/VIDEO RELEASE.

The Lease Contract will 
remain in force subject to: (1) abatement of rent on a daily basis during the 
delay; and (2) your right to terminate in writing.  After termination, you are 
entitled only to a refund of deposit(s) and to any rent paid.  If there is a 
delay and we have not given notice of delay as set forth below, you may 
terminate up to the date when the apartment unit is ready for occupancy, 
but not later. If we give written notice to you that the apartment unit is not 
ready but will be ready on a specific date, you may terminate the Lease 
Contract within one (1) day of your receiving the notice, but not later.  The 
date on which the apartment unit is ready is considered the new effective 
Lease Contract date for all purposes.
14.DISCLOSURE RIGHTS; PHOTO/VIDEO RELEASE.  If someone 
requests information about you or your rental history for law-enforcement, 
governmental, or business purposes, you hereby authorize us to provide it.  
If we are asked to provide your rental history to a mortgage or loan 
company or financial institution, you will be charged a processing fee of 
$10.  You also give us permission to use any photograph, likeness, image 
or video taken of you, your guests and occupants while you are using 
property common areas or participating in any event sponsored by us.
15.COMPLEX POLICIES OR RULES.  You and all guests and occupants 
must comply with written apartment rules and complex policies, including 
instructions for care of our Property.  Our rules are considered part of this 
Lease Contract.  We may make reasonable changes to written rules, 
effective immediately, if distributed and applicable to all apartment units 
in the Property.
16.CONDUCT.  Your apartment unit and other areas reserved for your 
private use must be kept clean and in compliance with all Governmental 
Codes.  Passageways may be used only for entry or exit.  Swimming pools, 
saunas, hot tubs, tanning beds, exercise rooms, storerooms, laundry rooms 
and similar areas must be used with care and at your own risk in accordance 
with apartment rules and/or posted signs.  We regulate: (1) the use of 
patios, balconies, and porches; (2) the conduct of furniture movers and 
delivery persons; (3) recreational activities in common areas; and (4) the 
exterior of the front door to your apartment unit which is part of the 
common area and not part of your apartment unit.  You'll be liable to us for 
damages to our regulated areas caused by you or any of your guests or 
occupants in these areas.  You are responsible for advising your guests and 
occupants of the terms of the Lease Contract and the attached Rules and 
Regulations.
We may exclude your guests or others from the Property who, in our 
judgment, violate the law, or the Lease Contract or any apartment rules, or 
disturb other residents, neighbors, visitors, or owner representatives, or 
exceed the number of guests we desire to be on the Property.  We also have 
the right to exclude you from the common areas and amenities (other than 
the mailboxes and ingress and egress paths from the Property) if, in our 
judgement, you violate the law, or the Lease Contract or any apartment 
rules, fail to pay your rent timely, or disturb other residents, neighbors, 
visitors, or owner’s representatives.
17.PROHIBITED CONDUCT.

You are responsible for advising your guests and 
occupants of the terms of the Lease Contract and the attached Rules and 
Regulations.
We may exclude your guests or others from the Property who, in our 
judgment, violate the law, or the Lease Contract or any apartment rules, or 
disturb other residents, neighbors, visitors, or owner representatives, or 
exceed the number of guests we desire to be on the Property.  We also have 
the right to exclude you from the common areas and amenities (other than 
the mailboxes and ingress and egress paths from the Property) if, in our 
judgement, you violate the law, or the Lease Contract or any apartment 
rules, fail to pay your rent timely, or disturb other residents, neighbors, 
visitors, or owner’s representatives.
17.PROHIBITED CONDUCT.  You, your occupants, and your guest may 
not engage in the following activities: (a) criminal conduct, regardless of 
whether or where arrest or conviction occurs, including but not limited to: 
manufacturing, delivering, or possessing a controlled substance or drug 
paraphernalia; engaging in or threatening violence; possessing a weapon 
prohibited by law; discharging a firearm in the apartment community; or, 
except when allowed by law, displaying or possessing a gun, knife, or other 
weapon in the common area, or in a way that may alarm others; (b) 
behaving in a loud or obnoxious manner; (c) disturbing or threatening the 
rights, comfort, health, safety, or convenience of others (including our 
agents and employees) in or near the apartment community; (d) disrupting 
our business operations; (e) storing anything in closets containing gas 
appliances; (f) tampering with utilities or telecommunications; (g) bringing 
hazardous materials into the apartment community; (h) using windows for 
entry or exit; (i) heating the apartment unit with a gas-operated cooking 
stove or oven; (j) intentionally or recklessly damaging our property or that 
of another resident or guest; (k) soliciting business or contributions or 
religious proselytizing; (l) operating a business from your apartment unit  
pursuant to which customers, clients, coworkers, or others enter the 
Property or your apartment unit for business purposes (conducting a 
business or working from home without business or employment-related 
visitors to the Property or your apartment unit is permitted); (m) having or

\5900 TX Tenant\5902 3 of 10using glass containers in the pool area; or (n) using candles, incense, 
kerosene or oil lamps.  Anyone using your key fob or access card to gain 
entry to the Property will be considered your guest for all purposes unless 
you promptly report the loss of any such device to us.  You agree to notify 
us within fifteen (15) days if you or any occupants are convicted of any 
felony, misdemeanor involving a controlled substance, violence to another 
person or destruction of property if it impact this community.  You also 
agree to notify us within fifteen (15) days if you or any occupants register 
as a sex offender in any state.  Informing us of criminal convictions or sex 
offender registry does not waive any rights we have against you.  You also 
agree that any complaints or criticisms of our business operation will be 
sent to us directly at the address set forth in Section 26 below and shall not 
be posted on any internet site.  Nothing in this prohibition should be 
construed as limiting your right to file suit against us for any damages or 
to make a formal complaint with an agency set up for that purpose.  You 
agree that odors emanating from your apartment unit which permeate 
another apartment unit are nuisances.  Further, as a result of such odors, 
you may be charged at move out for air duct cleaning treatment to return 
the apartment unit to condition received at move in.  Therefore, you must 
take all steps necessary to prevent such an occurrence.  For example, 
cooking with strong spices requires that the oven vent be operating 
constantly and may also require your purchasing an air purifier and placing 
it in a location close to the source of the odor.
18.PARKING RULES.  YOU ACCEPT RESPONSIBILITY FOR 
DAMAGES TO YOUR ASSIGNED GARAGE/CARPORT AREA, 
INCLUDING WITHOUT LIMITATION, DAMAGES TO THE 
DOOR, WALLS, FLOORS AND STRUCTURE, IF THESE ARE 
PRESENT.  Garage doors, if any, shall be kept closed when not in use.  
All vehicles must be in running condition and properly licensed.  A vehicle 
is prohibited on the Property and may be towed according to State Law at 
the vehicle owner’s or operator’s expense if it (1) has a flat tire or is 
otherwise inoperable for more than 48 consecutive hours; or (2) is on jacks, 
blocks or has a wheel missing; or (3) takes up more than one (1) parking 
space; or (4) belongs to a resident or occupant of a surrendered or 
abandoned apartment unit; or (5) is parked in a marked handicap space 
without the legally required handicapped insignia; or (6) blocks another 
vehicle from exiting; or (7) is parked in a fire lane or designated “No 
Parking” area; or (8) is parked in a space marked for other resident(s) or 
apartment unit(s); or (9) is parked on the grass, side walk, or patio; or (10) 
blocks garbage trucks from access to a dumpster; or (11) is in a space 
marked for office visitors except at specifically designed times; or (12) has 
no current license, registration or vehicle inspection certificate and we give 
you ten (10) days prior written notice of our intent to tow the vehicle if not 
removed; or (13) is not moved after notice to allow parking lot 
maintenance; or (14) is parked in any on-site location not consistent with 
the vehicle’s assigned parking permit.  Garages must be used for vehicle 
parking and may not be used exclusively for storage.  You may not store 
any items of personal property in your garage which would be a fire hazard 
or which are stored in an unkempt manner.  In private garages within 
parking structures, you may not store any items of personal property 
whatsoever.  You may not leave any animals in your garage, even 
temporarily.  You may not store any hazardous materials in your garage.  
You may not store any items of personal property in your carport.  
Charging of electric vehicles on the property is permitted in designated 
areas only.  Electrical cords may not be run from your apartment unit 
through common areas for this purpose.  Repairing motor vehicles is not 
allowed on the Property.  Car washing is only permitted in designated 
areas, if present.

Garages must be used for vehicle 
parking and may not be used exclusively for storage.  You may not store 
any items of personal property in your garage which would be a fire hazard 
or which are stored in an unkempt manner.  In private garages within 
parking structures, you may not store any items of personal property 
whatsoever.  You may not leave any animals in your garage, even 
temporarily.  You may not store any hazardous materials in your garage.  
You may not store any items of personal property in your carport.  
Charging of electric vehicles on the property is permitted in designated 
areas only.  Electrical cords may not be run from your apartment unit 
through common areas for this purpose.  Repairing motor vehicles is not 
allowed on the Property.  Car washing is only permitted in designated 
areas, if present.  There is a speed limit of five (5) miles per hour on all 
driveways.  All vehicles parked on the Property must have our prior 
authorization with our numbered permit sticker affixed in the upper corner 
of the front passenger side window.  Vehicles may not be backed into 
parking places unless the vehicle doors are impeded from opening by 
carport posts, and the vehicle has a front license plate.  Oversized vehicles 
and trailers (preventing the full use of adjacent parking spaces) are 
prohibited on the Property unless permitted by special parking 
authorization and payment of rental fees.  Motorcycles may only be parked 
in regularly marked parking spaces.  Parking on or about the Property is at 
your own risk.  Guest parking is not a condition of this Lease Contract, and 
when present, requires a permit (see rental office) displayed through the 
driver's front window.  All non-permitted vehicles are subject to tow-away 
at vehicle owner's expense.  You may not park any vehicle on the Property 
if the vehicle leaks or discharges any fluids.  If you violate this covenant, 
you agree to pay us cleaning charges and the cost of repairs to the asphalt, 
concrete, or other damages, to the extent deemed necessary by us.  You

MOLD AVOIDANCE POLICY.  If you 
discover mold in your apartment unit or you notice a damp, musty smell 
which may be caused by mold, you must notify us immediately and 
promptly follow this with a written complaint.  Upon receipt of your 
complaint we will immediately inspect the problem, determine the source, 
and perform remediation and repair.  If mold or musty conditions do exist, 
you shall have the right to vacate your apartment unit, which you must do 
as quickly as possible after we verify the condition, but in any case, within 
thirty (30) days after the condition is reported to us.  If it is your preference 
to move into another apartment unit at the Property and the condition was 
not caused by your negligence in maintaining your apartment unit or your 
failure to timely report a moisture problem, we will permit you to move 
into the same apartment unit type (subject to availability) at the same rent 
for the balance of your lease term, with rent paid and deposits transferred, 
subject to the other terms of your Lease Contract.  Unless this condition 
was caused by your negligence in maintaining your apartment unit or your 
failure to timely report the moisture problem, when you fully vacate your 
apartment unit pursuant to this Mold Avoidance Policy (a) you will be 
relieved of any further responsibility for the payment of rent under the 
terms of this Lease Contract, and (b) we will reimburse you up to $500 for 
your moving expenses upon your presenting us with valid receipts.  This 
payment is not available if you delayed in reporting a water leak from roof 
or plumbing defect.  If you elect to stay in your apartment unit 
notwithstanding this condition, we will act diligently to repair the 
condition.  However, you accept all responsibility for personal injury or 
property damage which results from your failure to terminate this Lease 
Contract and vacate your apartment unit pursuant to this Section.  In 
addition to this policy, please pay particular attention to the mold 
avoidance information in the Resident Handbook, a copy of which you 
received when you moved into your apartment unit.  If you fail to follow 
the tips described in the Resident Handbook, you will be responsible for 
any damage which results from your failure.  Your responsibility in this

36.INTERRUPTIONS OF OCCUPANCY.  If we believe that fire or

apartment unit to us in this condition.  We purchase a washable latex 
paint, and our experience indicates that under normal conditions we can 
wipe/wash down walls allowing thirty (30) months use before repainting.  
When possible, we selectively repaint areas.  Prior to vacating, you can 
wipe/wash down walls.  We prorate the cost of re-painting over thirty (30)

dated.  Carpet replacement for damages beyond normal wear and tear is

year wear dated.  Plank replacement for damages beyond normal wear and 
tear is prorated over one hundred twenty (120) months.  Mini blinds and 
drapes are prorated over thirty-six (36) months.  Formica counters are 
prorated over one hundred twenty (120) months.  If you vacate your 
apartment unit after defaulting in your obligations under this Lease 
Contract, you will also be charged for our cost in rekeying your apartment 
unit.  Damages and excessive wear are charged at the prorated cost of 
replacement, including labor, plus fifteen percent (15%) overhead. We do 
not have to refund your deposit until we receive your forwarding address,

and no deposit will be refunded unless and until all of the occupants 
identified in your Rental Application have vacated your apartment unit.

out inspection.  However, our representative has no authority to bind or 
limit us regarding charges for repairs, damages, or charges.  Any 
statements or estimates by our representatives are subject to our correction, 
modification, or disapproval before final refund or accounting.

(a)all rent must be current and you must make a written request for

(b)if we fail to do so, you must make a second written request for the 
repair or remedy after which we'll have a reasonable time for 
repair or remedy; and
(c)if the repair or remedy still has not been accomplished within that 
reasonable time period, you may immediately terminate this 
Lease Contract by giving us a final written notice.  You may also 
exercise other statutory remedies.
Instead of giving the two written requests referred to above, you may 
give us one request by certified mail, return receipt requested, or by

or remedy.  "Reasonable time" takes into account the nature of the 
problem and the reasonable availability of materials, labor and

These Rules  and Regulations are pursuant to the terms  of your Apartment

I. APARTMENT UNIT
1.Maintenance - Your apartment unit includes any patio, balcony, 
or backyard attached to your apartment unit.  You are required to 
keep your apartment unit in a clean and sanitary condition.  You 
may not obstruct any window or block any exit pathway since 
they may be necessary to exit your apartment unit in an 
emergency.
2.Embellishments And Decorations - Rugs, towels, clothes, 
flowerpots, planters, birdfeeders, or other objects shall not hang 
from windows, porches, fences, balconies, railings or private yard 
enclosures.  No electrical wiring or other type of support may run 
from inside your apartment unit through windows or doors or 
walls for any purpose.  The following are prohibited on balconies, 
patios and private yards: mops, brooms, toys, bicycles, trash, pet 
waste, newspapers or recyclables, machinery, recreational or 
other equipment.  Flowerpots on the patio or balcony floors shall 
have saucers placed beneath them and attended to regularly so 
that overflow water does not stain or cause deterioration of 
underlying surfaces.  No nails, screws or other means of 
attachment can be placed onto doors or other parts of structure.  
No types of structural changes are allowed in patio or private yard 
areas.  You may not modify existing building or structures 
including, without limitation, roofs, or awnings, materials 
attached to or leaning on the existing building or patio structures.
3.Apartment Unit Appliances - Your washer and dryer may be 
placed ONLY in the locations designated by plumbing, electric 
outlets, construction and venting.  Excluding household lamps, 
you shall not use any lighting fixture other than those furnished 
by us.  Heating appliances are prohibited.  No cooking devices 
are allowed in your apartment except as used in the kitchen: oven,

We would like you to be aware  of some important suggestions regarding your safety  and that of your family and your property.   
We recommend  that you consider  following  these suggestions, in addition  to other common sense safety practices.
PERSONAL SAFETY…WHILE INSIDE YOUR APARTMENT UNIT
1.Lock your doors and latch your windows even when you are inside.
2.If you have  night latches or dead bolts on the doors, use them while  you are inside  your dwelling.
3.When answering the door, first ascertain who is there by looking through a  window or  peephole.  If the  person is unknown,  
first talk with them without opening the  door and  don’t open the door until you feel  comfortable/safe  doing  so.
4.Be careful to whom you give or lend  your  keys.
5.Do not put markings  on your key ring identifying your  name or address.
6.If you are concerned  because you have lost your key or because someone whom you distrust has a key, ask the management 
to rekey the  locks, (which  we will do as long as  you pay the cost of rekeying in  advance).
7.Keep the  phone numbers for emergency medical services, the police or  sheriff departments and crime stoppers handy.
8.Periodically check your  door locks and window latches to be sure they are working  properly.
9.Immediately report to the management any needed repairs of locks, latches, doors, windows,  smoke detectors or carbon 
monoxide alarms.
10.Immediately report  to the management any malfunction  of other safety devices  outside your dwelling unit such as broken 
gate locks, burned out lights in stairwells and parking lots, etc.
11.Close curtains, blinds and window shades at night.
12.Let the manager and your friends know if you are going to be gone  for an extended time.  Ask your neighbors to keep  an 
eye on your dwelling  unit since management cannot assume that responsibility.
13.Mark or  engrave identification on valuable personal possessions.
PERSONAL SAFETY…WHILE OUTSIDE YOUR APARTMENT  UNIT
1.Lock your doors while  you’re  gone.  If you have a dead bolt, lock it too.
2.Leave a radio playing very softly  while you are gone.
3.Close and latch your windows when you are gone,  particularly on vacations.
4.Use lamp  timers when  you go out in the  evening or go away  on vacation.  They can be purchased at most hardware stores.
5.Tell your roommate or spouse where you are going and when you will  be back.
6.When walking  at night, walk with another person if at all possible.
7.Do not hide  a key under the doormat  or nearby flowerpot.  (That is the  first place  a burglar will  look.)
8.Do not give  entry  codes (where  applicable) to guests or strangers.
9.Make  arrangements for your newspaper delivery  to be stopped.
PERSONAL SAFETY…WHILE  USING  YOUR CAR
1.Lock your car doors while  driving.  LOCK your car doors and roll up the windows when leaving your  car parked.
2.HIDE all items in your car, such as audio tapes, wrapped packages, briefcases,  purses, etc. and do not leave valuables of 
any kind in your  car.
3.TAKE your keys with you!  If your vehicle is left for service or not under your control,  remove house keys and garage door 
openers and lock your vehicle registration  slip in the glove  compartment.
4.Carry  your key ring  in your  hand  while  walking to your car whether you are at home,  school, work or  on vacation.
5.Whenever possible, park your car in an off-street  parking area rather than on the street.  If parking on the street, park close  
to any nearby streetlight.
6.Remember to check  the back seat and under your car before getting into your car.
7.Do not stop at gas stations or automatic teller machines in areas  of town with increased crime or at night if there is any 
suspicion of danger.
No one can guarantee your safety.  The most elaborate precautions (such  as alarm systems,  security guards, patrol cars and 
electronic gates) do not safeguard  against crime.

certain Apartment Lease Contract (“Apartment Lease” and together with

\4800 Resident Handbook\48031.RENTAL PAYMENTS  - YOU HAVE TWO BASIC  METHODS - NO COST VERSUS ADDITIONAL FEE
Verify your payment method  since fees/costs may change.  Determine if there  is a bank  charge  for your personal checks or basic  
checking account.
(a)Pay Rent From Your Personal Bank Account.  You will need an established checking account at a bank  which  provides 
Automated Clearing  House  (ACH) payments.  There is no additional  charge to you for either of the following two payment 
methods:
(i) For your greatest convenience, make ACH  electronic payments online through the  Resident  Portal at  
http://rentanapt.com/estatesonfrankford.  Your  bank information can be saved for future  payments and/or submitting 
Service Requests online.   Here are the steps to register and set-up your  account:
(1)Visit  http://rentanapt.com/estatesonfrankford.
(2)Click Resident in the top right.
(3)Click Register  Now  and follow the  steps.
(4)Check your email that you associated  with this  account for your password.
(5)Return to http://rentanapt.com/estatesonfrankford and log-in.
(ii) Bring your check  into the office  for deposit  by us.
(b)Pay by  Money Order.  The cost varies but may be less expensive than  a credit  or debit card payment.
(c)Pay By Credit Or Debit Card.  Using the Resident Portal at http://rentanapt.com/estatesonfrankford and selecting  this 
payment method creates a fee of about 3% of the amount transferred.
If you need  assistance, please email  or phone the on-site  office.
2.SERVICE REQUESTS FOR MAINTENANCE 
The most  convenient method for making a service request  is by creating your account on our Resident  Portal  using  the instructions 
in Section  1.(a)(i)(1)-(5) above.
3.ONLINE COMMENTS/REVIEWS
Most prospective residents  understand that some of the issues  presented in online reviews reflect frustrations unrelated to the 
property or have been attended to by management.  Our reputation is to promptly respond  to our residents’  needs.  If you have  an 
issue, please complete  a Service Request or report it to the Leasing office.  We strive  to maintain our apartments  for your pleasure 
and living convenience. We appreciate comments/reviews that  recognize our  efforts and reflect your enjoyment of  the property.
4.MANAGEMENT MOVE-IN SERVICE
As soon as it is convenient after your move-in, contact  the office so that we can assist  you in the operation of various  appliances:  
oven; clothes washer; proper loading of the clothes dryer; microwave use; dishwasher.
5.PACKAGE CONCIERGE
Upon move in, you will receive  an email  from  Package  Concierge with the subject  line “Welcome to Package Concierge”.   You 
will be assigned a user name and given a link to follow to create a PIN and select a contact method.   You will be able to choose 
whether to be contacted by email, text or phone  call anytime  a package is delivered for you.  You can retrieve  your package  at any 
time from the Package Concierge by entering your Username and PIN.  There will also be an in depth  video  included in your 
welcome email on how to retrieve your packages from Package Concierge.  You will receive a second notification  once the package 
has been  in the locker for five days, or becomes “stale”.  Packages that remain longer than that could be returned to the sender.   
Each resident on the lease will have their own unique user name and PIN.  Packages are only delivered to lease  holders or occupants, 
as specified  by you  when registering  with Package  Concierge.

7.RESIDENT PERSONAL  PROPERTY INSURANCE
Damages/loss of your personal property is not the responsibility of the owner or management.  We recommend that you carry 
insurance but do not require  it unless you are bringing your pet into the  dog park.
8.FIRE HAZARD – Kitchen is #1; Bedroom is #2; Fireplace is  #3; BBQ’s is  #4!
If conditions are safe, first phone the fire department  then our on-call maintenance  person.
(a)If you do not own a fire extinguisher,  we encourage you to buy one.  We recommend a fire extinguisher  labeled  all purpose for 
combinations of inflammables: grease; oil; gasoline; electrical.  Management  experience is that this may save considerable loss 
of property.  We will refund  to you 1/3 of your cost up to $10.  Remember, first protect  lives, then dial 911 and, if safety permits, 
attempt to put out  the fire.
(b)Keep matches out of reach  of children and away from sources of  heat such as  kitchen ranges or heaters.
(c)If fire occurs  from cooking, do not use water.  WATER SPREADS A GREASE FIRE!  For large grease fires or if a small 
fire is not very quickly  extinguished, call 911 immediately.  For small grease fires, first turn off the heat.  The most effective 
means to put out a small grease fire, in order, are: (1) using a dry chemical-type or all-purpose extinguisher; (2) using baking 
soda, if available; and (3) by smothering the fire by covering the pot or pan with a lid.  If no lid is available, you may also 
smother a grease  fire by thoroughly  soaking a towel  with water and covering the grease  fire.  If you throw a wet towel on the 
fire, do not tip  the pot or pan over as it  spreads the fire very quickly.
(d)DO NOT BURN CANDLES, INCENSE, OR USE  OIL  LAMPS.
(e)Never  smoke  when  working around flammable liquids  or oxygen tanks.  Make  sure matches  and smoking materials are 
fully extinguished before  disposing of them (pinch  the ends of objects which were  lighted before  placing  them in trash  cans).

\4800 Resident Handbook\4803If you smoke, use large, non-combustible  ashtrays in every room.  Do not smoke  in bed.  You may fall asleep.  Stay awake and 
sober if smoking in a  soft chair.
(f)Keep storage areas and closets cleared of old rags,  papers, mattresses,  broken  furniture  and other combustible materials.  Never 
store gasoline or other flammable liquid  in your apartment, garage or patio/balcony  area.  Propane containers are not permitted 
in resident controlled areas.
(g)After using oily polishing rags, place  them in metal covered cans.   Paint  and varnish, etc., must be kept in tightly closed 
containers.  Never  use gasoline, benzene or other flammable liquids for cleaning  clothes, furnishings, appliances, floors or 
anything else.  Some of these  chemicals  may cause cancer.
(h)We recommend against using the fireplace because it is a fire hazard.  Most of  the heat  energy  goes  out the chimney.   
(i)Cooking Device not provided by the owner - these may not be used  or stored on a patio or balcony or in a garage  or 
apartment.
(j)Do not use portable electric heaters.
(k)For patio/balcony barbecue/charcoal  grills see rules and regulations.
(l)When grease, fat, lard or cooking oil overheats, it will smoke just before catching  fire.  Immediately turn the heat down or off.  
Keep your kitchen range, including the oven and broiler, free of  grease.
(m)Fire in the oven can usually  be extinguished  by closing the oven door and turning off the heat or using  a dry, chemical-type 
extinguisher.  Call 911.
(n)Stove burners can ignite loose fitting shirts,  blouses, pajamas and robes.
(o)Do not leave cooking  food unattended.  Keep pot handles turned in  and away from edge of stove.
(p)Do not keep items desired by children  on or above the stove.
(q)Know your  various exits in case  of fire.
(r)Do not store combustible  materials on balconies  or in hallways or stairways where fire could  prevent  escape.
(s)In case  of fire, check  door handles for  heat  before  opening  doors.
Electrical Hazards
(t)Never replace a  fuse.   Call Management.  For electrical outages, have flashlights and batteries on hand.
(u)Be sure appliance  cords are not worn or frayed with loose prongs.  Pull cords out by holding the plug, not the cord.  Avoid  
using extension cords with multiple plugs.  Unplug irons & similar appliances when not  in use.
(v)Do not run electrical cords  under rugs, through doorways  or over  hooks, radiators, heaters, pipes or ducts.
(w)If cracked sockets or hot switch plates  call management.
9.INTRUDER ALARM
For units without a built-in alarm, residents are urged to purchase an alarm  security device.   Such devices  are available  at most 
electronic stores and either plug into a wall outlet or operate with a battery.  When set, these devices  detect movement and the 
resulting loud noise will generally cause an intruder to leave the apartment.  The cost for these devices  is extremely small compared 
to what is lost when a  burglary takes place.  In addition, such an  alarm  may also protect your person as well.
10.ELECTRIC ENERGY SAVING TIPS
Turn off all lights when not in use.  Clean lamps,  fixtures and diffusers on a regular basis for best lighting.   If you are using  a “night  
light” try the one watt,  LED  photocell which can be placed in an electric  outlet.  See also: Cooling and Heating System;  Clothes 
Dryer and Washer.   Dimmer  Switch – You must  hear a click  by either depressing the knob or completely  turning the knob to the 
“off” position (depending upon type of switch).   If you merely turn the switch until the light is no longer on, the light is not off and 
you still will be using the same  amount of electricity as if the light were fully bright.
Sunscreens (West, SW & East Facing  Windows and Sliders) - Sunscreens reduce energy cost and prolong furniture  life.  Contact 
on-site management to determine the  increased rent charge depending upon the number and size of  sunscreens requested.

11.WATER CONSERVATION
Even if your water  is not being allocated, you will receive a copy of the Addendum for Allocation to review ways to conserve  water,  
our most important natural resource.  Contact the on-premises manager immediately  if you do not have  water saving devices  in the 
toilet tank, showerheads and faucets or if they malfunction.  Removing these  devices  evokes  penalty  clauses  in your Lease.  
Immediately request maintenance  for any water dripping  or leaking.  Periodically check under  sink for hidden leaks and check your 
hot water heater for rusting or leaks, especially if there is decreased temperature or duration of hot water.  Run each sink faucet  for 
1-2 minutes  before drinking if the water has not have been turned  on for a  number of weeks.

\4800 Resident Handbook\480312.GENERAL CLEANING GUIDELINES:
Fiberglass Tub/Shower  – After use, wipe down the tub ledge, where the tub meets the wall.  Caulking  may be cleaned and whitened 
with Clorox Cleanup®  or similar product.
Grout/Caulking – Request a  service  call.
Ceiling Fan Care  – Fans  tend to collect  dust during the winter when there is less use.  Place each fan blade inside a pillow  case to 
wipe each blade and  catch the  dust.  Then wash off the blades  with plain water and  dry.
Window Blind  Care – Vacuum regularly with a brush attachment to prevent dirt build up.  A dry microfiber cloth also may be 
used.  Do not spray a glass cleaner on blinds or shades  because it will stain the blinds.   Before raising or lowering the blinds,  always 
turn the blinds  to the open  position.
Contact Paper – Do not use contact paper to line drawers or shelves because it cannot be easily removed, resulting in increased 
charges on move-out.
Stainless Steel Appliances – Like wood, steel has a grain.  An entire sheet of steel will have  the same direction grain but an 
individual appliance may have different pieces of steel used for different  parts such as handles and knobs.  Wiping in the correct 
direction will prevent cleaning residue and grime from  getting deeper into the crevices of the grain.  Apply a small  amount of dish 
soap to a damp 100% cotton,  non-abrasive cleaning rag or paper towel (never  use an abrasive cleaner and scratcher sponge).  Wipe 
along the grain line of your appliance.  Stubborn areas may need to be gone  over several times.  Use a dry towel to remove any 
water marks  after thoroughly cleaning an area.  Lastly, polish the surface with a small (a couple drops) amount of baby/mineral oil 
on a fresh rag  or paper towel.   Follow the grain of the  steel back  and forth when applying.
Stainless Steel Sinks – Hope’s  “Perfect Sink” cleans, shine and protects SS  sinks.   Available at Home Depot.
13.AUTOMATIC DISHWASHER
Resident Use
(a)Wash  full loads only.  Before using, make  sure disposal side of sink is free of garbage, stopper  is removed and no water is 
standing in sink.  Use only for intended purpose.  Never clean filters  in the dishwasher.
(b)Inspect dishwasher base beneath basket for glass, garbage, paper, silverware,  etc., dropped from prior loads.  Remove  if present.
(c)Before placing dishware and silverware in dishwasher, remove all food debris  and garbage by scraping  off all food material.  
Dishwashers are  not garbage disposals.
(d)Load basket so glass will not strike other  dishware and  pots/pans as  breakage  may occur.
(e)Secure all plastic and wood dishware and utensils  to eliminate movement or floatation as they may be damaged  by the heating 
element or  cause a fire.
(f)Use correct detergent.  The most common  source of damage  to dishwashers  is the use of the wrong detergent.  Only detergents 
specified for a dishwasher  should  be used and in the exact quantity suggested  by the manufacturer.  Place 1-2 tablespoons of 
dishwasher crystals in the soap dispenser and close cover.  In order to prevent  caking, detergents should be added immediately 
before the dishwasher  cycle is to begin.  In hard water areas,  use a rinsing  agent.  Keep detergents and rinse  agents away from 
children.
(g)Position drying  agent ("Jet  Dry" basket) so  water from  spray arm can dissolve and  disperse  it properly.
(h)Loading - load only dishes and utensils  for dishwashers.  Generally, metal items should be placed away from  the detergent.  Do 
not place  large objects  next to the detergent  cup or smaller objects.  Secure lightweight items so that they will not be moved by 
water force.
(i)Roll baskets in and close door.  Turn  timer  to "START" position and latch  door, interlocking arm.  Note:   If operations sequence 
does not begin, manually advance timer slowly until water fill is  heard.
(j)Once cycle has begun, do not interrupt or open  door until  timer is in  "OFF" position.

In hard water areas,  use a rinsing  agent.  Keep detergents and rinse  agents away from 
children.
(g)Position drying  agent ("Jet  Dry" basket) so  water from  spray arm can dissolve and  disperse  it properly.
(h)Loading - load only dishes and utensils  for dishwashers.  Generally, metal items should be placed away from  the detergent.  Do 
not place  large objects  next to the detergent  cup or smaller objects.  Secure lightweight items so that they will not be moved by 
water force.
(i)Roll baskets in and close door.  Turn  timer  to "START" position and latch  door, interlocking arm.  Note:   If operations sequence 
does not begin, manually advance timer slowly until water fill is  heard.
(j)Once cycle has begun, do not interrupt or open  door until  timer is in  "OFF" position.
(k)Before removing baskets, make sure silverware is not hanging down which  will cut tub  liner.
(l)For energy conservation, select the air-dry option,  if present, or turn the machine off  after the last rinse.
(m)If you do not regularly  use the dishwasher, run it  at least one time per  week.
Resident Care of Dishwasher  – Every 4-6 Weeks:
(a)Place one cup vinegar and  ¼ cup salt  in dishwasher  and run through complete cycle.
(b)Take a teaspoon handle and remove debris  from front corners,  right  and left of tub where  door  gaskets meet rub  gasket.
(c)Clean soap dispenser.   Remove  old soap.  Clean  door  gasket with  warm  water and  cleanser.
(d)If your  dishwasher has  a filter screen,  it should also be cleaned  periodically.

\4800 Resident Handbook\4803Dishwasher Cleaning
(a)The exterior cabinet of the dishwasher is finished with durable  baked-on enamel.  Use a high-grade wax cleaner when necessary.  
Avoid harsh cleansers or abrasive scouring pads  that will scratch the surface.
(b)Never use scouring pads or cleansers.   Dishwashers may have  a plastic screen/grate at the bottom to catch food, debris,  etc.  
Clean with a wet  cloth or use the “heavy clean” setting.
14.CLOTHES DRYER & WASHER
Dryer:  Resident  Care
(a)Daily, clean the lint trap  before every dryer load and use a  vacuum to remove any  lint from the exhaust duct.
(b)Use in the early evening rather than daytime when temperature exceeds 75°.
Washer:  Resident Care
(a)Wash  only full loads to save energy.
(b)Over  sudsing causes leaks and blocks drains.  To reduce the suds, pour ½ cup white vinegar mixed  with cold water into the 
washer.  Next time, use less detergent  (try a  low-suds type).
(c)If washer will not spin or begins to vibrate,  the wash load may be too large  or out of balance.  Try removing  some items  or 
redistribute the load.
(d)Do not allow the washer to run when you are not in the apartment.   If the washer overflows or the water hose leaks, you must 
be around to prevent damage to  flooring  and/or carpet.
15.COOLING & HEATING SYSTEMS
Energy Saving  Tips
(a)Filters need changing when you cannot distinguish  the blue/green color.  We change filters  during apartment turnover and 
quarterly.  If you believe our policy was not followed or that your filters  should be changed, request a service call or obtain 
filters from the  office.
(b)Digital  Thermostat – if you need this device, contact  the office.   There’s no additional  charge to you for the unit or installation.  
During the day, close windows, doors,  drapes and blinds (set mini-blinds  with the leading  edge  up) to reduce heat gain.   Shaded  
rooms are cooled more  easily and economically.  Close vents  and doors  to rooms that are not being  cooled or heated.  Set the 
fan to “auto” so that it only runs when the unit is operating.  Maximize the extent you can use ceiling fans rather than expensive 
air conditioning.
(c)Temperature  settings should be set to increase  or decrease the temperature generally from daytime to nighttime.   There should  
be a minimum of 2-3° difference between heating and cooling so that the functions  are not constantly alternating off and on.  
In setting  the air conditioning to cool,  read the thermostat as “cool to” or, if heating, the temperature is set “heat to.”  Instructions 
for the digital, programmable  thermostat are available in your  hiring packet, as well as via email.
(d)Never obstruct  the flow of air with furniture,  as this will cause short cycling and  poor operation.
(e)Appliances (dishwasher, clothes washer/dryer)  give off heat that the air conditioner must  reduce.  Minimize the use of 
appliances during the warmest part  of the day.
(f)When cooking, use the vent fan.  It will send heated  air directly outside.  When  pre-heating the oven,  10 minutes is usually 
sufficient.  When  cooking on the stove top, match the diameter of pots and pans to those of the heating elements to prevent 
heat from escaping and  less heat  escapes  if pots and pans are covered.
(g)Keep furnishings at least  three feet  away  from  a wall heater.
Heating:
(a)When going to bed, set thermostat “heat to” 63° - 64° F and use layered blankets/comforters.   When leaving  the apartment,  be 
sure the heating  is “on” if temperature is at  or approaching freezing.
(b)Management  can assist with  cleaning/replacing  filters, checking flue pipes, connectors and gas vents.
Cooling:
(a)Set the air control  to “CLOSED” or “RECIRCULATE”.
(b)Never operate an air conditioner  without a filter in place.  The humidity increases when the A/C is on.  Generally,  A/C “set to” 
76° - 78°  is sufficient and saves electricity.

(g)Keep furnishings at least  three feet  away  from  a wall heater.
Heating:
(a)When going to bed, set thermostat “heat to” 63° - 64° F and use layered blankets/comforters.   When leaving  the apartment,  be 
sure the heating  is “on” if temperature is at  or approaching freezing.
(b)Management  can assist with  cleaning/replacing  filters, checking flue pipes, connectors and gas vents.
Cooling:
(a)Set the air control  to “CLOSED” or “RECIRCULATE”.
(b)Never operate an air conditioner  without a filter in place.  The humidity increases when the A/C is on.  Generally,  A/C “set to” 
76° - 78°  is sufficient and saves electricity.
Fan Use:
(a)In winter, the ceiling fan should operate  in a clockwise direction on low speed to create a gentle updraft which forces warm  air 
near the ceiling downward.
(b)In summer,  the fan should  rotate  in a counterclockwise  direction.
(c)Review comments on the internet to determine  if you want to sleep with a fan on at night.   There are a number  of considerations.

16.GARBAGE DISPOSAL
Resident Use
(a)Before operating, always start cold water running.
(b)Grind all waste as soon as it is placed in the  disposal.
(c)Do not put fibrous  material, bones,  pits, poultry skin, corn shucks,  onion  peels, raw celery, asparagus, spinach, shrimp skin, 
cigarette filters, refried beans, toothpicks, eggshells, or uncooked chicken  skin  in disposal.
(d)Coffee grounds – first, turn on the cold water to run forcefully, then feed the grounds  slowly into the disposal which will allow 
them to disperse and not compact in the drain line.  Otherwise, the coffee grounds  pile up in the pipe and, overtime, pack  the 
pipe completely.
(e)Completely grind  vegetable peelings in small  amounts with other food wastes;  place fibrous vegetable materials in a plastic 
lined trash  receptacle.
(f)Never overload disposal; jamming results when wastes are compacted.
(g)Never dispose of grease,  oils or cooking fat in drains or garbage disposal.
Please do not pour grease down garbage disposal/drains.  Grease  floats on water  and sticks to pipes.  It is not dissolved by 
hot water.
(a)Keep an old milk carton or  frozen juice container under your sink.  Pour cooled oil  (salad/frying/bacon) into the container and 
throw it out with your trash.
(b)Use a paper  towel to wipe  off dishes and pots coated  with grease before washing or placing these items in  the dishwater.
(c)Scrape fat dripping  from  meat into a  plastic bag or container and toss it in the trash.
(d)Please tell your children about the  importance of these measures.
Resident Care If Disposal Becomes Inoperative – Request a Service Call
(a)Turn wall switch off  and switch electrical breaker "Off" (or unplug under sink).
(b)Visually check for foreign obstacles, bones, silverware, pits, pop tops, etc. and remove  any debris.
(c)If jammed and no key is available, use broom or  mop handle to  move the rotor blade.  Remove debris.
(d)Plug unit in.  Push  "RESET" on bottom  of disposal.
(e)Turn cold water on (heavy stream).
(f)Flip wall switch to "ON" position  and flush thoroughly for  fifteen seconds.
(g)If unit will not operate,  check "RESET"  button  on bottom of disposal  and electrical breaker  for "ON" position.   Call 
management.
(h)Never use  chemical drain  openers in disposal.  Permanent damage may occur.
(i)Weekly, flush  the garbage disposal by filling the sink with three inches of water, then draining  while the disposal  is in operation.
(j)You are responsible for maintenance and repairs of the garbage disposal if the problem results from your abuse. For example,  
when refried beans are put into the garbage disposal, this causes "sticking" and malfunction.
(k)Resident Care of Sink/Drains - to prevent clogging sink pipes, pore ½ cup baking  soda into drain,  then pour ½ cup vinegar 
over it.   Repeat at regular intervals as needed.
17.KITCHEN RANGE
Electric/Gas Range: Resident Use
(a)If the range does not work request a service  call.
Oven/Cooktop: Resident Care
(a)General cleaning  should  be done  on a regular day-to-day basis.   If electric, turn off power supply at  breaker before cleaning.
(b)Always  clean  spillovers  immediately.  This is the largest cause  of burner and pilot  malfunctions.
(c)Clean hood and filter regularly for safe use.  Grease build-up on the hood can  cause a  fire.

immediate service.

18.MICROWAVE
Use of Microwave  - Call maintenance to change the light  bulb if access requires removal  of screws.   To maximize value and 
use, purchase  a microwave  cookbook.
(a)Some products such  as whole eggs and sealed containers  such as  closed, glass jars may explode in the microwave.
(b)Do not use appliance  if the cord or plug is damaged.  Call Management immediately.
(c)Do not cover or block any openings in the appliance.  Keep cord away from heated  surfaces.
(d)Do not immerse the cord or plug in water.  Do not let the  cord  hang  over  the edge of the table or counter.
(e)Avoid a fire in the  oven:
(i) Do not overcook food.  Carefully observe the  microwave if paper, plastic or  other combustible materials are placed  
inside.
(ii) Remove wire twist ties from paper or plastic  bags before placing in  the oven.
(iii) If materials inside the oven should ignite, keep the  oven  door  closed, turn the  oven  off and disconnect the  power  cord  
or shut off power at  the fuse or circuit breaker panel.  If necessary, call  911, then  spray with  fire retardant chemical 
and call 911.
(f)Use extreme caution when removing the tray or disposing of hot grease.  Cool grease  can be disposed of in a used can or 
container and place it in a plastic  lined  trash receptacle.
(g)Do not touch  hot surfaces.  Use handles or knobs and pot holders.
(h)Do not use metal dishes or utensils with metal trim  in the microwave.
(i)Plastic containers - cook  only if labeled microwave safe (no margarine or cottage cheese cartons).  Chemicals from some  
plastics may leach  into food.
(j)Do not attempt repairs yourself.  Do not use newspapers  in place of  paper towels.
(k)Do not try to dry clothes or other materials in the  oven.  They will catch fire.
(l)Do not use aluminum foil  in the  microwave.
(m)Do not cook directly on paper  towels or napkins unless indicated by cookbook  and microwave directions.
(n)Do not use recycled paper products since their impurities may cause sparks or fire.
(o)Never use  your microwave for home canning.
(p)For defrosting  foods, defrost  charts  are available  in various cookbooks.
(q)Some foods should not be completely defrosted before cooking, e.g. fish.
(r)When using timer, begin by using minimum time  and check occasionally for doneness.  Avoid overcooking.
(s)Some quantities of  food with  low moisture content  may  burn or dry  out and become hard  if cooked too long.
(t)Do not boil eggs in their  shell; they may  burst.
(u)Foods with non-porous  skin or a  membrane  such as  apples,  potatoes  or egg yolks should  be pierced  to prevent bursting.
(v)When cleaning surfaces of the door and oven, use only mild, non-abrasive soaps or detergents applied with a sponge or soft 
cloth.  Rinse  and dry with a soft cloth.
(w)Clean around the  seal.  Keep the seal clean.

Food Storage  Tips
(a)For peak  flavor, store  foods in the proper compartment.  Leafy  vegetables, green beans and citrus fruits stay fresh  longer when 
stored in the moist  environment of the vegetable bin.
(b)Refrigerate only those meats you plan to use in one or  two days.  Use the freezer for longer storage.
(c)Wrap or  cover all  food to prevent odor transfer.
(d)Organize food storage for convenience.  Store all like things together  and rotate  foods  using  the oldest first.  Put frequently 
used items  in front or in door shelves.  Allow for  air flow  between frozen  items.
(e)Freeze only  top quality  foods  in freezer  packaging.
Energy Saving  Tips
(a)Store only foods that  require refrigeration.
(b)Do not overcrowd the  refrigerator.  Do not overload door shelves.
(c)Allow warm or hot foods to cool before placing them in the refrigerator or  freezer.
(d)Make  sure all doors are  properly cleaned and sealed.  Request maintenance  if necessary.
(e)Eliminate unnecessary opening of the door.  After opening,  close the door as  quickly as  possible.
(f)Wipe all  moisture  from  bottles and cartons before placing  them in the  refrigerator.
20.TOILET
LO-FLOW – Too much  thick dual ply tissue causes blockage  and overflow.  Of course, other major causes of blockage are cotton 
swabs and inappropriate  paper/objects dumped into the toilet.  Never flush wipes  or feminine products  down the toilet, even  if they 
claim to  be “flushable”.   Avoid pass-through service call costs to clean inappropriate blockages and  keep  a plunger handy.
Overflow Control – Our “gift” toilet plunger  can come in handy.  If a toilet is about to overflow, quickly lift off the cover on 
the water tank.   This water is clean.  Above the water outlet pipe is a rubber gasket which generally floats down to cover the opening.  
Push the gasket down to cover the opening.   Usually, you can hold the gasket over the opening  while  you turn-off the water inflow 
valve in a clockwise  direction on the wall behind the toilet.  This process should  prevent water damage to the floor and carpet.  With 
the water overflow problem stabilized,  use the plunger.   For best results, tip the plunger into the toilet water to allow water to fill 
the cup before plunging.  Plunging with water  in the plunger  cup works much  better  clearing the clog.  Rapidly pump the plunger a 
dozen times or more to force release  of the obstruction.  If the maintenance request  is due to resident negligence, there  is a service 
fee charge.  Do not leave the dwelling with a toilet running or filling.
21.HOT  WATER AND HOT  WATER HEATER
Water faucet and shower head temperature  should be 120º F or less to avoid  scalding.   Anytime you are concerned  about the 
temperature of your hot water, call maintenance  immediately and do not turn on hot water.  Water  temperature above 125º F can 
cause severe burns instantly or death from scalding.  At 140 º F, hot water can produce 3rd degree burns  in less than 5 seconds and 
in 30 seconds at 130º F.   You may test water temperature at a faucet  by using an oven  thermometer.
Whether or not the hot water heater has been on or off, if you have  not used hot water for two weeks  or longer, hydrogen gas can 
collect in the heater.  To prevent possible damage or injury,  run hot water from the kitchen faucet  for several minutes  before  using 
the dishwasher or any other  appliance using hot water.  This will allow hydrogen to escape (you may hear a slight  hissing or 
sputtering noise from  the faucet as the water begins to flow).

Do not store anything within two  feet of  the water heater.
22.CEILING FAN LIGHTING FIXTURE
Do not exceed 60-watt bulbs in these fixtures.   Higher  watt  bulbs are a fire hazard.  Please use lamps for additional lighting.  
Based upon a study in the Archives of Pediatrics,  use the bedroom fan to circulate bedroom air may lower the risk of sudden infant 
death syndrome.

\4800 Resident Handbook\4803Routine Cleaning – Wipe with a damp cloth  or sponge using a mild soap,  non-bleach detergent.   If grease  is present,  use an 
ammoniated or  vinegar based glass cleaner.  Do not us an abrasive cleaner or  powder  or scouring pad.
Cleaning Various  Stains:
Food Stains – Use a short, soft-bristle nylon brush with a mild soap, non-bleach  detergent.  This should  also remove  water 
marks, glass rings, and  fingerprints.
Ink Stains/Pencil Marks – Remove quickly  with a glass spray cleaner.  Allow cleaner to remain on the stain for several 
minutes.  Blot with a damp  cloth and rinse.  If the stain persists, use denatured alcohol,  fingernail  polish remover, mineral 
spirits or paint  thinner.
Paint and Adhesive Stains – For water based paint, use an ammoniated household detergent.   For super glue, use nail polish 
remover or  acetone.  For oil-based paints, try paint  remover with caution as  solvents are extremely flammable.
Precautions - Do not place hot pans or dishes directly  from the burner or oven  onto the laminate.   Burning  cigarettes  will destroy 
the surface.  Avoid contact with chemicals since  many will cause permanent damage.  Avoid cutting directly on the countertop 
surface with knives or other  sharp objects  as they may damage  the countertop.
24.GRANITE, QUARTZ  AND ARTIFICIAL COUNTERTOPS  AND  SURFACES  – CARE & MAINTENANCE
Avoid Damage to the Countertop - Use the plastic  cutting  board as a place  for hot pots and pans.   Never place a hot pan or pot 
from the stovetop or oven on the counter surface.  Damage to the countertop will result  and require the  countertop to be replaced.
Routine Cleaning  - Dust surfaces  frequently with a soft, clean  cloth.  Blot up spills  immediately, before  they penetrate the surface.  
Clean surfaces  with a few drops of pH balanced  dishwashing liquid and warm water.  Rinse  after washing  with the soap solution 
and dry completely with a soft, clean cloth to avoid  streaks.   Scrape  off any hard substances  stuck to the surface and lime build up 
by gently  scraping  with a  hard,  thin object like a debit card or new single, sided razor  blade.
Granite, Quartz and Artificial Countertops and Surfaces: The following products  are recommended for routine cleaning  of 
these surfaces:  Weiman  Granite & Stone daily cleaner & polish, Method Granite Cleaner,  Therapy Clean  Granite and Stone  Cleaner, 
Bar Keepers Friend Granite & Stone  Cleaner. NEVER USE  LYSOL OR SIMILAR TYPE  PRODUCT.
Avoiding Scratches - Knives  will become dull very quickly if used on the counter surface, and may also damage the counter.   The 
following will scratch the surfaces: quartz and diamonds; stoneware dishes containing rough silica sand; pizza-stones; and marble 
cutting boards.
Avoiding Chips - Chips  are most often caused by banging something  into the edge  of the countertop.  Avoid putting any 
unnecessary weight on the edges or surface of the countertops.  If a chip does occur and you find the piece that chipped out, save it 
and submit a service request for repairs; in some cases a chip can be re-attached by our  maintenance staff  at lesser  cost to you.
Sealing the Granite and Stain  Removal - If you believe your granite countertops are in need of sealant or stain removal, submit 
a service  request to management.
Precautions - Don’t leave acidic liquids (vinegar, lemon juice, orange juice, lime juice, soft drinks and wine)  on granite surface.  
Do not use the following cleaning  agents: bleach, ammonia, acid or alkaline, grout, abrasive liquid  or powder, lime removers, stone 
sealers, and tub and tile.  Do not store bottles of cooking oil, metal pots  and pans directly on your  counter  tops.
Thank you.
