\4800 Resident Handbook\480326.“FAUX WOOD”  VINYL FLOORING – CARE & MAINTENANCE
YOUR “FAUX  WOOD” FLOORING IS A VINYL  SURFACE.  CAREFULLY READ THE INFORMATION BELOW  
REGARDING THE CARE AND MAINTENANCE OF THIS  FLOORING.
While “faux wood” flooring has a tough, protective finish and is moisture  resistance, it still requires special attention when cleaning 
to avoid damage.
(a)Follow these proper care and maintenance  guidelines:
(i) Sweep the floor regularly with a soft bristle broom to remove loose dirt; 
(ii) Wash  the floor  with a  non-abrasive, neutral  pH floor cleaner;
(iii)  For everyday  maintenance, you can mop the floor with warm water;
(iv) Clean spills immediately (see below);
(v) Furniture  legs are a potential source of damage to the floor.  Narrow  metal or dome-shaped glides or  footings on 
furniture legs should not be placed directly  on the flooring.  To  avoid damaging  the flooring, be sure that the legs are 
placed on non-staining  felt pads or plastic  floor protectors.  These  protectors should  be at least one inch in  diameter 
and rest flat  on the  floor.  The heavier the  item, the wider the  floor protector should  be.  
(vi) Heavy furniture or appliances that are not moved  often (couch,  washer, dryer, etc.) should  have flap cups under all 
elements of the furniture  or appliances  which touch the ground.
(b)DO NOT USE the following on “faux wood” flooring:
(i) Soap based detergents;
(ii) Abrasive mop and shine  products;
(iii) Floor wax;
(iv) Ammonia  or bleaches  (for spot treatment, a diluted solution of  one part bleach  to ten parts water is acceptable for stain 
removal); and
(v) Vacuum cleaners with rotating beater bars.
Always read the cautionary  information on all cleaning  products prior to use!
(c)Moving furniture or  appliances across “faux wood”  flooring:
Never push, pull or drag furniture,  appliances  or other  items across the floor.  When moving furniture  or heavy items, they 
must be lifted and carried whenever possible.  If the furniture cannot be carried and set in place  (like a washing machine), place 
furniture sliders  or hard  boards  between  the flooring and the object which is being moved  to avoid  damage.
(d)How to treat  stains,  spills and scuffs:
Unless instructed  otherwise, treat the stain, spill or scuff with a product recommended  for vinyl flooring  using a clean white 
cloth or towel.  Always rinse the affected area with a clean, wet towel after treatment.  Keep traffic off the treated areas for 30 
minutes.  For stains  or spills  such as acids, alkalis, blood, catsup, mustard, food,  fruit,  fruit juices, candy,  cleaners, strong soaps, 
dye, dye markings, urine and feces, grass, iodine, mercurochrome and rust, proceed as  follows:  
(i) Remove as much  solid material as possible;
(ii) Scrub the  area  with a  full strength cleaner approved for vinyl;
(iii) Rub the  area  with a solution of 10 parts of water to 1 part  liquid  bleach;
(iv) Rub the  area  with isopropyl  alcohol;  and
(v) If rust stains do not respond, use  lemon  juice  or a cream of  tartar solution.
(e)Paint and Solvent Spills:
These consist of dry cleaning fluids,  lacquer  and latex  paint, nail polish, solvents, oil-based paints, wood  stains and varnish.  
To treat these  spills proceed as follows:
(i) If the substance is  dry, gently peel  it up from the floor.  Do not use sharp instruments that  could  scratch the floor 
during removal; or
(ii) If you are unable  to peel the material up from the floor, scrub the area with a non-abrasive cleaner approved for vinyl; 
or
(iii) Lightly rub the  area with odorless mineral  spirits or paint  thinner. 
(iv) Do not use acetone or nail polish remover on “faux  wood” floors.

(e)Paint and Solvent Spills:
These consist of dry cleaning fluids,  lacquer  and latex  paint, nail polish, solvents, oil-based paints, wood  stains and varnish.  
To treat these  spills proceed as follows:
(i) If the substance is  dry, gently peel  it up from the floor.  Do not use sharp instruments that  could  scratch the floor 
during removal; or
(ii) If you are unable  to peel the material up from the floor, scrub the area with a non-abrasive cleaner approved for vinyl; 
or
(iii) Lightly rub the  area with odorless mineral  spirits or paint  thinner. 
(iv) Do not use acetone or nail polish remover on “faux  wood” floors.
(f)Substances that do  not wipe up – adhesives, chewing gum, oil,  grease, candle wax and  tar.  To treat these areas:
(i) First, remove as much  solid material  as possible using the blunt surface  of a spoon;
(ii) Then scrub the area  with a non-abrasive  cleaner;
(iii) Finally, rub the area lightly with odorless  mineral  spirits, isopropyl  alcohol or  lighter fluids.

27.CARPET CARE & MAINTENANCE 
Stain Removal – Treatment  of the affected area should begin immediately upon discovery. The more time that elapses before 
treatment, the more difficult a stain will be to remove.
(a)First, scrape food spill gently with a spoon or dull  knife, removing as  much  solid material as  possible.
(b)Try to remove  stains with warm water only. If a stain  cannot be removed with a warm  wet cloth, or warm water extraction, 
apply low-residue  carpet  spot remover  (with the  Carpet and Rug  Institute Seal of Approval) to  the stain.
(c)Working from outer  edge  toward the center to avoid  spreading, blot with a clean cloth or paper towel. Do not rub or scrub. 
Continue to spray  and blot until the stain is gone. Do not over-saturate carpet.   Use small amounts of solution and blot 
frequently.
(d)Important: Maximum pH of cleaning chemical should be pH 10 or less.  Before using,  always test cleaners on a small,  non-
visible area for  any discoloration of the pile.
(e)Abnormally large or excessive stains may require hot water  extraction  method (140 degrees maximum temperature). 
Professional cleaning  is recommended.
(f)If a stain returns--a condition known as ''wicking''--simply  repeat stain removal procedures, paying  special  attention to blotting 
and removal of all moisture.
Regular Vacuuming – Most  dirt, and even dust, takes the form of hard particles. When left in the carpet,  these gritty, sharp particles 
abrade the pile of the carpet.  Regular vacuuming  not only prolongs the life of the carpet but will enhance its appearance as well. 
Most soiling in carpet  is of the dry particle type which  can be removed with a vacuum cleaner.  Vacuum high-traffic areas daily, 
medium-to-high traffic areas  twice weekly, and the entire  house at least  once a week.

holding the dish must not exceed five (5) feet in height.
(b)Wires must  be run to the  unit as previously indicated.
(c)The location of the satellite dish must  be where it can be partially shielded  by landscaping and out of common traffic areas.  
We have  the right to finally  approve  the location of  all such satellite dishes and change these regulations  at will.
29.TRASH DISPOSAL
In general, place trash  in bags for convenience  in transporting  trash to the dumpster.  Some  city regulations require that trash is 
sorted (management  will advise you).
Assisted Trash  Collection  – For projects which offer this service, your trash must be placed in the designated location at the 
designated day and time for pick-up.  Trash must  be in a plastic bag with a tie top.  Improper bags which leak or are placed on non-
designated pick-up days will be returned to you and you will be billed  penalty fees.  Obviously,  placing trash for pick-up  on non-
designated days is unsightly and attracts pests.
30.MOLD/MILDEW AVOIDANCE POLICY AND REMEDIATION (See your Lease Agreement.)
We are committed to promptly making repairs to remove sources  of water or moisture and to accommodate  your moving out of the 
apartment according to our lease  provisions.   Of course, no one can prevent  you from vacating your apartment.
Mold grows where there is moisture, dampness, or humidity.   You must promptly  notify us if (a) you find any areas  in your 
apartment unit which are damp,  or (b) if you detect a musty smell in your apartment unit.  On your part, you should take action to 
prevent moisture  or dampness by inspecting your apartment unit regularly and  reporting to  us, as  follows:
(a)Cabinets below sinks  – Look for leaks in the kitchen and bathrooms, and wherever a  sink  is present.
(b)Shower  area – Look for signs of moisture on the top ledge of the wall tile and note if the fixture  covering  the shower pipe as it 
exits the wall is loose or lacks caulking.
(c)Look for stains  in the ceiling or  walls or around window casings.
(d)Check appliances, such as  the washing  machine hose and  hot water heater, for signs  of water leakage.
(e)Remove any visible moisture accumulating  on windows,  walls, ceilings, floors  and other surfaces as  soon as possible.
(f)Turn the kitchen exhaust fan on before you start cooking  to prevent  the build-up  of steam.
(g)When showering, be  sure  to keep the  shower curtain  inside the bathtub  or fully close the shower doors.
(h)Be sure the bathroom exhaust fan is on when hot water is used or the mirror shows  fogging.  Keep the fan on until all moisture 
on the mirrors and/or  bathroom walls and tile surfaces has evaporated.  Avoid hot showers/baths during the warmest hours of 
the day.  Long  hot showers/baths significantly increases  both electric  and water cost.  Keep the bathroom  door closed when in 
use with the exhaust  fan on to remove and prevent warm moisture from  circulating throughout  the apartment.  Bathroom 
humidity may cause damages to venting and walls, including mildew.
(i)The presence of  indoor plants  requiring watering may increase moisture which promotes mold/mildew.
(j)Propping furniture, boxes or other objects closely against  wall  surfaces leads to mold/mildew.
(k)Constant, low temperature air-conditioning not only wastes energy but increases the accumulation of condensation along A/C 
lines promoting mold/mildew.

31.PESTS
(a)Roaches:   The following pertains to items which attract ants as well as roaches.  All insects  are driven by chemicals in their 
search for food and water.  Roaches and ants have a keen sense  of smell.  Roaches will be attracted to and eat anything that has 
nutritional value (omnivores).  They are especially attracted to starch,  sugar, grease,  meat,  cheese, decaying food items.   They 
will find tiny particles left on plates, pots, pans, scraps  falling  from the table, and remnants left on counter top or in pet dishes.  
Roaches need moisture  to survive and this search may bring  them into even the “cleanest  of homes.”  Leaky pipes and faucets 
are reasons roaches may travel to bathrooms, kitchens and laundry rooms.  This is one of the reasons why we ask residents to 
immediately request maintenance if you observe a water leak problem.  Additional information is available on numerous  
websites.  You will be charged for a vendor visit if we treat for roaches during  your occupancy and our photos demonstrate 
that you permitted items which attract roaches by insufficient cleaning.  
(i) Do not keep brown-paper grocery sacks  around  since they may  be contaminated  with  roach eggs.  Roaches  can thrive 
in the  dark folds of paper sacks.
(ii) Do not leave food uncovered.
(iii) Promptly  clean food, crumbs and  liquid spills.  Sweep and mop  the kitchen floor  regularly.
(iv) Vacuum carpets frequently  to remove crumbs and other food particles dropped  by people and  pets.

\4800 Resident Handbook\4803(v) All trash must be  placed in plastic bags with tightly  sealed ties before  being  placed  in the dumpster.   See  the lease  
“Addendum for Valet Waste Removal.” 
(vi) Store pet food in well-sealed containers.   Water bowls should be cleaned daily.  Food  bowls should be cleaned 
immediately after the  pet is  finished  eating.   Wet  pet food  quickly attracts  roaches.  
(vii) Use aerosols only for flying insects.
(b)Ants:  Use a least expensive enclosed bait station  which indicates “kills the colony in 24 hours” or similar.   Wait  24 hours and 
the trail of ants will disappear, having  brought  the "food" back to  the queen  to her detriment.
(c)Scorpions:  Certain  areas of the country  such as Arizona and Texas  have  scorpions.  Immediately advise the office if you see 
one.  We will promptly inspect and perform mitigation.  Scorpions cannot jump.  Scorpions do not nest.  Pesticides do not 
eliminate scorpions.  Phoenix Children's Hospital  sees many more patients each month during the summer  months than during 
the winter.  In case of scorpion sting, immediately cover the area with ice and seek medical attention.   Without  anti-venom, 
symptoms can last up to 24 hours.  Infants and young children are at greater  risk.  A national hotline  has been provided for 
information, prevention and treatment  of poison at (800) 222-1222, or visit www.poisoncontrol.com (Texas)  or visit 
www.bannerhealth.com (Arizona) and search for poison  for more information.  Additional measures you can take to avoid 
contact with scorpions are: a) Put crib and other bed legs in a clean, wide-mouth jar.  Scorpions cannot climb  on clean glass; 
b) Wrap bed legs with duct tape (sticky-side up); c) Pull beds away from walls; d) Shake  clothing before putting on; e) Place 
baking soda, talcum  or body powder under  kitchen  sinks and in closets along  the edges.
(d)Mosquitoes:  Mosquitoes breed in areas  of standing  water and have a range in flight of a number of miles.  If you have  planter 
saucers or pet water bowls, be sure these are emptied daily.  If you find any such areas on the premises, immediately  report this 
to our office.   Generally, mosquitoes are most active  from dusk until dawn;  however, another type of mosquito with dark bands  
around its legs is active during the day.  Different varieties of mosquitoes  carry different diseases which spread to humans  if a 
mosquito is carrying  the infectious agent, generally a virus.  Minimize exposed  areas  of the skin and apply mosquito repellent 
containing DEET or equivalent repellent.  Call maintenance if you observe standing water on the premises. Remember, if you 
have potential breeding areas  on your patio or balcony such as small plants in pots with saucers which  have standing water, 
you may be breeding mosquitos.
(e)Bedbugs:  Bedbugs are blood-feeding, brownish-red insects, about  ¼ inch long and flat.  Once they've had a blood  meal, they 
swell and turn a dark reddish-brown.  These insects live in cracks  and voids  near areas frequented by people, usually in 
bedrooms or other sites where people might  sit or rest. Their flattened shape allows them to easily slip into narrow places  in 
mattress seams, bed frames, headboards, bedside furniture, behind pictures and switch plates,  behind  baseboards,  under buttons 
on mattresses and in box springs.  If you believe you are being bitten by bedbugs,  examine these places  closely, using a 
flashlight to help look for the adult bugs as well as their tiny, whitish eggs.   The nymph  form may give off a musty, sweet odor.   
You should also inspect all luggage and clothes for bedbugs when returning from a trip.  Also look for bedbugs on second-
hand items before bringing them home.  Don’t buy second hand furniture  without  a very close inspection.  Their bite is nearly 
painless and usually goes unnoticed  by most people.

The problem must  be professionally treated and if untreated,  may spread quickly.   In cases of heavy infestation additional 
measures such as encasing mattresses, box springs and pillows  in cover slips to seal in the remaining bed bugs or discarding 
mattresses, couches, chairs and other bulky fabric furniture may be called for.  Clothing can generally be washed and dried in 
a hot dryer and hard surfaces can be cleaned.   Your vigilance is necessary in avoiding this possibility.   Dogs  are the most 
accurate detectors  of bedbugs.  See internet for additional  information.
A vendor charge  is passed on to you under the following  circumstances.  Our policy is to have  a State  Licensed vendor 
appropriately inspect and treat each unit prior to new occupancy.  Bedbugs are brought into the premises by the resident on articles 
of furniture, bedding,  clothing, luggage,  etc.  Therefore,  there will be a vendor  charge for extermination  if bed bugs are found  after 
your tenancy begins.
32.PEST  CONTROL

market.  The apartment, cupboards, closets, should be thoroughly cleaned; 2) When  you receive notice of regular pest control 
treatment, advise the office  and vendor in advance that  you are refusing treatment.
To prepare for a Professional Exterminator, contact the office for your appointment, day and approximate time.  Follow these  
instructions.  Remove and clean all kitchen items located  in cupboards, cabinets, shelves  and drawers.  Place all items on counter 
tops or tables and cover  these items.  Clean drawers, cabinets, pantry, and shelves using a damp cloth and cleanser and wipe  
dry.
(a)Floors – Must be free of debris and  cleaned.   This includes rooms and closets.
(b)Bathrooms – Remove  contents of medicine chest and cabinets, place items in  the bathtub  and cover these items.
(c)Bedrooms – Remove just enough garments from closets to permit easy movement within.  Remove  drawers from  dressers so 
inside of  dresser casings  can be sprayed.   Place the contents on your bed  or tables.

40.RENTING VS. BUYING
Home buyers should consider all of the additional costs of ownership and future sale.  At the start,  there  are escrow  closing costs, 
fees, and loan points.  The interest rate may involve  a “mortgage insurance fee,” essentially, an addition to your interest  rate.  The 
mortgage lender has fire and liability insurance requirements.  While you may want the protection  of renter’s  insurance, we do not 
require it.
Home ownership requires a payment of property taxes and, in addition, condominium ownership involves monthly Association 
dues.  Maintenance  and  replacement costs are frequently underestimated or unbudgeted by the homeowner:  roof; appliances 
(heating, air conditioning systems; hot water heater; dishwasher; refrigerator; oven; clothes washer and dryer; garbage disposal);  
carpet/flooring; and plumbing & electrical problems; landscape maintenance; termite control.  Will you be a jack-of-all-trades or 
hire reliable contractors?  Compare these costs with the known cost of leasing.  At the time of house  sale, you immediately  lose 
commission costs from  the house  value and  may  take a significant loss on the  sale.
Personal obligations and employment  opportunities may pressure a house  sale under adverse  market conditions.  Renting gives 
mobility to take advantage  of new,  employment opportunities.  The value of your home mortgage  income tax deduction is 
substantially diminished, and may be exceeded, by non-deductible ownership expenses as cited  above.   As a renter,  an income tax 
credit may be available.
House/Condominium Renting  – Apartment  renting offers significant advantages over renting  a house or condominium.  House  
rental may require that the resident is responsible  for landscape,  pool upkeep  and appliance repair.   Not infrequently, a house  renter 
cannot rely on the owner or management company to promptly  meet obligations to repair the roof, fix leaks or perform other, needed 
repairs.  With condominium renting, there are generally  inconsistent rental  criteria  and policies by individual condominium owners 
which may result in failure to remedy reasonable complaints.  Certainly, you will not have  access  to the range of amenities  at large 
apartment complexes, particularly  the extraordinary amenities offered at most Management Support  properties.
41.MOVE-BACK AND REFERRAL BONUSES
If you leave a Management Support  managed apartment  in good standing and return to a Management Support apartment, you will 
receive a bonus  of $300 off the first full month's rent in addition to any then existing  concessions.   Also, please  contact our on-site 
Manager regarding our bonus for referring  new  residents  to us.

\4800 Handbook\4805REWARD NOTICE
Reward Conditions :  We are as concerned about your property as our own.  As a result, we are offering a reward 
as described in this Reward Notice.   To qualify  for a reward, submit information regarding the criminal  acts 
outlined below in accordance with this Reward  Notice.  If your information leads to the arrest, conviction and 
subsequent incarceration of any person(s)  involved in the criminal acts outlined below  (except incarceration is 
not required for the $500 reward) you will be entitled to the reward.  A reward is not available to anyone  involved 
in the criminal activity reported or sharing the reward with a person  involved  in the crime.  Only one reward is 
payable per incident or group of related incidents (by time and date).   If more  than one person  qualifies 
for a reward, the reward is equally divided  among qualifiers.  MS employees can qualify  for 10% of the 
indicated rewards (minimum $100).
Being alert and suspicious may help you to earn a reward.  Pay particular attention to persons you deem suspicious, 
and those driving vans or trucks, particularly if the vehicles do not meet our aesthetic standard.  Such vehicles 
may have no license plate(s) or a paper plate(s)  or plate(s) covered in clear plastic or other  obscuring material.  
Also pay attention to persons driving and looking around with no apparent  direction.   If you believe you are 
observing a criminal act, promptly call 911 and the  office manager indicating an  emergency.
Taking care not to put yourself  in danger,  take photos of the vehicle, license  plate, and occupants.   Note  the 
location, time and date.  Give your information  to the police and to our apartment manager.  Save your photos or 
print them  out.  Your photos and  actions can qualify  you for a reward according to the conditions  of this notice.
We are offering the following rewards for information regarding  the theft, intentional damage or vandalism to 
our real and personal property or that of our residents, and for information regarding illegal drug activity  on the 
property.  Examples include theft,  vandalism, arson, and damages to mechanical/electric gates, fencing/walls,  
mailboxes, vehicles, TVs, or computers.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$10,000 REWARD
Theft of or intentional damage to one or more  items of personal or real property  with an original  or current 
aggregate value greater than $5,000.  Intentional damage or vandalism to a lessee’s vehicle is included in this 
reward.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$5,000 REWARD
Theft of or intentional  damage or vandalism to real or personal property (other than vehicles)  with an original or 
current aggregate value from $1,000 to $5,000.  The manufacturing or sale  of drugs on our property.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$500 REWARD
Vandalism such as, but not limited to, graffiti, throwing trash or debris  about the property or in the pool instead 
of in designated areas, vandalism to walls, fences  or gates.  Theft of or intentional damage  to one or more items 
of personal  or real property with an original  or current aggregate value less than $1,000.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
All information will be kept confidential except as required by law enforcement demands.  Send  information to: Executive  
Secretary, Management Support, 1800 E. Deere Ave., Santa Ana, CA  92705 or msadm@rentanapt.com, or fax  (949) 251-9417.
IF YOU  WISH TO PROVIDE INFORMATION  AND NOT IDENTIFY YOURSELF,  USE THE  FOLLOWING PROCEDURE:
1.Send information  to us and use an identifying  code  number.  You should also send a copy of the information  to the local police

2.When conviction  occurs, send a second letter indicating  your code number.  We will substantiate law enforcement  action.  Also

This Addendum for Water/Wastewater  Allocation and Billing is 
attached to and made a part of that certain  Apartment Lease  Contract  
(“Apartment Lease” and together with this Addendum, the “Lease”), 
which you (the Resident) have entered into with us (the Owner).  To the 
extent there are any inconsistencies  between  this Addendum  and the 
Apartment Lease, the  terms  of this Addendum shall control.
Allocation.  You and we agree to the water allocation system 
described below,  regarding water and wastewater.  During  the lease term 
and any extensions  thereof, we are authorized to allocate a portion  of the 
monthly water/wastewater bill(s) for the apartment community.   The 
allocation will be based on the number of occupants in your unit.  This 
allocation method is described in the Texas Administrative Code, Title  
16 (16 TAC), Chapter 24, Subchapter I.  More  specifically, the allocation 
will be completed as  follows:
1. Your monthly rent under  the lease does not include a charge for 
water and wastewater.  Instead,  you will receive  a separate bill from 
the vendor doing the billing for such  utilities.
2. Your monthly water/wastewater bill will be calculated  based  on an 
allocation method that is approved  by the Public  Utility 
Commission of Texas (PUCT), as follows: Your monthly 
water/wastewater bill will be calculated based on your per person  
share of the previous month’s actual water/wastewater bill for the 
Property.  Before calculating  your portion of the bill, we will deduct 
for irrigation of landscaping and all other common area uses, as 
required by PUCT Rules.  We will also deduct and separately  bill 
you for any utility company per-unit base charges and customer  
service charges  so that you won’t  be paying  any part of such charges  
for vacant units.  However, you will be responsible for your 
proportionate share  (on a per unit basis) of any governmental fees 
charged on  our water/wastewater bill.
“Per person  share” means the number of occupants in your 
apartment unit divided by the number of occupants in all apartment 
units in the Property.
3. No administration or other  fee will be added to the total 
water/wastewater bill(s).  Penalties or interest  for any late payment 
of the mastermeter  water/wastewater bill by us will be paid for 
entirely by us  and will not be allocated.
4. This method of determining  your allocated share of the 
water/wastewater bill will not change  during your lease term 
without your prior written  consent.   We do have the right to change 
the allocation formula,  to the extent  permitted  by the PUCT, only 
when (a) a lease is signed by a new resident;  or (b) a renewal lease 
is signed by you upon  not less than thirty five (35) days prior notice.5. Payment  of the allocated water/wastewater bill is due and should  be 
paid with your next rental payment, unless the water bill is 
postmarked less than sixteen  (16) days before your next rental 
payment is due, in which  case, your bill should be paid with the 
following month’s  rental payment.  (If your bill is hand delivered to 
you, the date of delivery will be substituted for the postmarked 
date.)  You will be charged a five percent (5%) late charge if your 
payment is not paid on or before your rental due date.   A summary 
of PUCT  rules regarding water/wastewater allocation is attached to 
this Addendum.
6. You may examine  our water/wastewater bills and our calculations 
relating to the monthly allocation of the water/wastewater  bills 
during regular  weekday office hours.  While  it is not required,  it will 
lessen delay if you give us reasonable advance notice to gather the 
data.  Any dispute relating to the computation of your bill will be

\5900 TX Tenant\5901 DAA CHECKLIST OF  WATER  CONSERVATION IDEAS FOR YOUR DWELLING
In the bathroom...
Never use  the toilet to dispose of cleansing tissues,  dental  floss, cigarette butts or other  trash.
When brushing your teeth, turn off the  water  until you need to rinse your  mouth.
When shaving, fill the  sink  with hot water instead of letting the faucet run.
Take a shorter shower.   Showers may use up to 50% of interior water consumption.
Take a shower instead  of filling the tub and taking a bath.
If you take  a tub bath, reduce the water level by one or two inches.
Shampoo your hair in the shower.
Test toilets for  leaks.   Add a few drops of food coloring to the water in  the tank, but  do not  flush.  Watch to  see if the coloring 
appears in the bowl within a  few minutes.  A slow drip can waste  as much  as 170 gallons a  day or 5,000 gallons  per month.
In the kitchen...
Run your dishwasher  only when you have a full  load.
If you wash dishes by hand, don’t leave  the water running for rinsing.   Try  filling the sink  instead.
Use your  sink disposal sparingly, and never for just a few  scraps.
Keep a container of drinking water in the  refrigerator.
When cleaning vegetables,  use a pan of cold water rather than letting the faucet  run.
For cooking  most food, use only a little water in the pot and put  a lid on it.
When doing  the laundry...
Only wash  full loads  of laundry or adjust  the water level  to match the size of the load (if this is an option).
Use cold  water as often as possible to save energy and to conserve the hot water for  uses which cold water cannot serve.

\5900 TX Tenant\5907ADDENDUM FOR ALLOCATION OF STORMWATER/DRAINAGE COSTS – TX
Complex Name: Estates on Frankford Apt #: 3123
This Addendum  for Allocation of Stormwater/Drainage  Costs  is 
attached to and made a part of that certain  Apartment Lease  Contract  
(“Apartment Lease” and together with this Addendum, the “Lease”), 
which you (the Resident) have entered into with us (the Owner).  To the 
extent there are any inconsistencies  between  this Addendum  and the 
Apartment Lease, the  terms  of this Addendum shall control.
1. Governmental  entities  impose stormwater/drainage fees to help pay 
for the cost of maintaining  the infrastructure needed to prevent 
flooding and lessen the impact  of pollution on our water  system.  
These fees can be significant.  Our property  has chosen to allocate  
these fees so residents  are more aware of the true costs associated 
with these fees.  Your monthly rent does not include  a charge for 
stormwater/drainage costs.  Instead, your utility bill will also 
include as a separate  and distinct charge the stormwater/drainage  
costs allocated to you on a  per dwelling  unit basis.
2. A monthly administration  fee of $3.00 per month will be added to 
the total stormwater/drainage  cost bill(s).  Penalties or interest  for 
any late payment  of the stormwater/drainage  bill by us will be paid 
for entirely  by us  and will not be allocated.3. This method of determining  your allocated share of the 
stormwater/drainage costs will not change during your lease term 
without your prior written  consent.   We do have the right to change 
the allocation formula,  to the extent  permitted  by the PUCT, only 
when (a) a lease is signed by a new resident;  or (b) a renewal lease 
is signed by you upon  not less than thirty five (35) days prior notice.
4. Payment  of the allocated stormwater/drainage costs is due and 
should be paid with your next rental payment, unless the 
stormwater/drainage cost bill is postmarked less than sixteen  (16) 
days before  your next rental payment is due, in which  case,  your 
bill should be paid with the following month’s rental payment.  (If 
your bill is hand  delivered to you, the date of delivery will be 
substituted for the postmarked date.)   You will be charged a five 
percent (5%) late charge if your payment is not paid on or before 
your rental due date.
5. You may examine our stormwater/drainage cost bills and our 
calculations relating to the monthly allocation  of the 
stormwater/drainage costs during regular weekday  office hours.  
While it is not required,  it will lessen delay  if you give us reasonable 
advance notice to gather the data.  Any dispute relating to the 
computation of your bill will be between  us and no one else.

Complex Name: Estates on Frankford Apt #: 3123
This Addendum for Valet Waste Removal  is attached  to and made a part of that certain Apartment  Lease Contract (“Apartment 
Lease” and together  with this Addendum, the “Lease”),  which you (the Resident) have entered into with us (the Owner).  To the extent  
there are any inconsistencies between this Addendum and the Apartment Lease, the terms  of this Addendum shall  control.
1.Your  monthly  charge  for trash removal  is: $19.00
2.Payment of your portion of the trash removal  cost is due and should be paid with and as part of your next rental payment.  Late 
charges will accrue pursuant to the terms  of your Lease if your payment is not paid on or before  your rental due date.  Your 
portion of the trash  removal cost is considered rent due us and is added  to your rental payment as set forth above.   If the 
outstanding amount is not paid when due, we  may  refuse your  entire  rental payment.
3.The amount which you are being  charged for trash removal is the amount we are charged  by the valet waste provider and the 
current trash removal vendor,  and any related costs.  If the rate for valet  waste and/or trash  removal to us increases or decreases, 
upon thirty (30) days prior  written notice to you, we have the right to change  the amount you will pay for trash  removal to 
correspond to the new cost to us of trash removal,  whether or not  the current term of your  Lease  has expired.
4.You may examine our trash  removal/recycling  bill and the calculations we make to determine your monthly trash 
removal/recycling charge,  and any changes thereto  pursuant to Section 3 above,  during regular weekday office hours.   While 
it is not required, it will lessen  delay  if you give  us reasonable  advanced  notice to gather  the data.
5.Valet trash service is currently  provided to each resident 5 nights  per week (Sunday  - Thursday).  We may change or eliminate 
this service  entirely by providing you with thirty  (30) days prior written notice  of such change or elimination.  While this 
service is in effect,  a container will be provided for each apartment  and must be used in conjunction  with the valet service.  
Containers with bagged trash must be placed outside your front door only between the hours of 6:00pm - 8:00pm.   Pick-up 
service will begin  at 8:00pm.
6.All trash  must be in bags  which are securely tied.  These bags must  be placed into the container.  Your trash will not be 
collected unless you follow this procedure.   No loose trash  will be collected.   All boxes must  be broken down  and flattened.  
After collection, resident must  bring  their container inside the apartment prior to 9:00am the following morning.  There is 
a $50 charge to the resident if an additional or replacement  container is needed or if the container is not left in the apartment  
when you vacate the premises.  If you miss service on any of the designated nights, you must bring the trash to the designated 
compactor or dumpster area or keep the trash inside your apartment  until  the next collection evening.  Containers/trash 
may not be left  out for any reason  during non-designated  times.
7.If you do not comply with the instructions,  you will receive  a warning.   If there is another violation after a warning, your 
container will be removed and/or a fine of $50 will be issued.  Containers  may be returned after your return fee is paid providing 
you indicate  an understanding of the service procedures.   If a problem continues,  your valet service will be terminated and 
disposing of trash will become your responsibility.
